description:
'''Ashley Nicolette Frangipane''' ({{IPAc-en|IPA|ˌ|f|r|æ|n|dʒ|ᵻ|'|p|ɑː|n|i}} {{respell|FRAN|jih|PAH|nee}}; born September 29, 1994), known professionally as '''Halsey''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|h|ɔː|l|z|i}} {{respell|HAWL|zee}}), is an American singer-songwriter and actress. Noted for her{{efn|Halsey uses both [[She (pronoun)|she/her]] and [[Singular they|they/them]] pronouns and switches between them; this article uses she/her pronouns for consistency.}} distinctive singing voice, she has received several accolades including three [[Billboard Music Awards|''Billboard'' Music Awards]], a [[Billboard (magazine)|''Billboard'' Women in Music Award]], an [[American Music Award]], and has received nominations for three [[Grammy Awards]]. She was on ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]''{{'s}} annual list of the [[Time 100|100 most influential people in the world]] in 2020.

Halsey was born and grew up in [[Central Jersey]]. Gaining attention from self-released music on social media platforms, she signed with [[Astralwerks]] in 2014 and released her debut [[extended play]] (EP), ''[[Room 93]]'', in October of that year. Her debut studio album, [[Badlands (Halsey album)|''Badlands'']] (2015), was met with critical and commercial success—debuting at number two on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]]. It was certified double platinum by the [[Recording Industry Association of America]] (RIAA), along with its singles "[[Colors (Halsey song)|Colors]]", "[[Gasoline (Halsey song)|Gasoline]]" and "[[New Americana]]", the latter of which became her first entry on the US [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] at number 60.

In 2016, Halsey co-performed with [[the Chainsmokers]] on their single "[[Closer (The Chainsmokers song)|Closer]]", which topped the charts in the US and ten countries, while receiving 14× platinum certification by the RIAA. Her second studio album, ''[[Hopeless Fountain Kingdom]]'' (2017) embodied a more "radio-friendly" sound and debuted atop the ''Billboard'' 200, while its singles "[[Now or Never (Halsey song)|Now or Never]]" and "[[Bad at Love]]", both entered the top 20 of the ''Billboard'' Hot 100—the latter peaked within the top five. Her 2018 single, "[[Eastside (song)|Eastside]]" (with [[Benny Blanco]] and [[Khalid (American singer)|Khalid]]), found continued success and peaked within the top ten. Later that year, she was moved to [[Capitol Records]].

Halsey's third studio album, ''[[Manic (Halsey album)|Manic]]'' (2020), became her best selling album worldwide. Its lead single, "[[Without Me (Halsey song)|Without Me]]" topped the ''Billboard'' Hot 100, received [[RIAA certification|diamond certification]] by the RIAA, and yielded her furthest commercial success as a lead artist. Her fourth album, ''[[If I Can't Have Love, I Want Power]]'' (2021), moved away from her previous sound in favor of a darker [[Industrial music|industrial]] sound to generally positive reception. She then parted ways with Capitol in 2023, following a controversy surrounding the release of her non-album single, "[[So Good (Halsey song)|So Good]]" the year prior. After signing with [[Columbia Records]], Halsey's fifth studio album ''[[The Great Impersonator]]'' followed in 2024. By 2020, [[Billboard (magazine)|''Billboard'']] reported that her albums had sold over one million combined units, and received over six billion streams in the United States. Aside from music, she has been involved in [[suicide prevention]] awareness, [[sexual assault]] victim advocacy, and [[racial justice]] protests.
